natural problem: Each of five, standard, six-sided dice is rolled once. What is the probability that there is at least one pair but not a three-of-a-kind (that is, there are two dice showing the same value, but no three dice show the same value)?
natural solution: There are a total of $6^5=7776$ possible sets of dice rolls.

To get a pair without a three-of-a-kind, we can either have one pair and the other three dice all showing different numbers, or we have two pairs and the fifth die showing something different. In the first case, there are $6$ ways to pick which number makes a pair and $\binom{5}{2}=10$ ways to pick which $2$ of the $5$ dice show that number.

Out of the other three dice, there are $5$ ways to pick a value for the first die so that that die doesn't match the pair, $4$ ways to pick a value for the second one so it doesn't match that die or the pair, and $3$ ways to pick a value for the last die so that it doesn't match any of the others.

So there are $$6\cdot 10\cdot 5 \cdot 4 \cdot 3 = 6^2 \cdot 100$$ways to roll this case. In the second case, to form two pairs and one die not part of those pairs, there are $\binom{6}{2}=15$ ways to pick which two numbers make the pairs, then $4$ ways to pick a value for the last die so that it doesn't match either of those pairs.

There are $$\frac{5! }{2!\cdot 2!\cdot 1! }=30$$ways order the five dice (equal to the number of ways to order XXYYZ),  so that makes a total of $$15\cdot 4 \cdot 30 = 6^2\cdot 50$$ways to roll this case.
This makes a total of $$6^2 \cdot 100 + 6^2 \cdot 50 = 6^2 \cdot 150 = 6^3 \cdot 25$$ways to roll a pair without rolling a three-of-a-kind.
So, the probability is $$\frac{\text{successful outcomes}}{\text{total outcomes}}=\frac{6^3 \cdot 25}{6^5}=\frac{25}{6^2}=\boxed{\frac{25}{36}}.$$

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P :: "rat"
assumes h0 : "P = (25 / 36)"
shows  "P = (Probability_of_exactly_one_pair - Probability_of_three_of_a_kind) / (Number_of_dice_roll_possibilities)"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Each of five, standard, six-sided dice is rolled once. What is the probability that there is at least one pair but not a three-of-a-kind (that is, there are two dice showing the same value, but no three dice show the same value)? The final Answer is \frac{25}{36}
 ### Proof
 There are a total of $6^5=7776$ possible sets of dice rolls.
 To get a pair without a three-of-a-kind, we can either have one pair and the other three dice all showing different numbers, or we have two pairs and the fifth die showing something different. In the first case, there are $6$ ways to pick which number makes a pair and $\binom{5}{2}=10$ ways to pick which $2$ of the $5$ dice show that number.
 Out of the other three dice, there are $5$ ways to pick a value for the first die so that that die doesn't match the pair, $4$ ways to pick a value for the second one so it doesn't match that die or the pair, and $3$ ways to pick a value for the last die so that it doesn't match any of the others.
 So there are $$6\cdot 10\cdot 5 \cdot 4 \cdot 3 = 6^2 \cdot 100$$ways to roll this case. In the second case, to form two pairs and one die not part of those pairs, there are $\binom{6}{2}=15$ ways to pick which two numbers make the pairs, then $4$ ways to pick a value for the last die so that it doesn't match either of those pairs.
 There are $$\frac{5! }{2!\cdot 2!\cdot 1! }=30$$ways order the five dice (equal to the number of ways to order XXYYZ),  so that makes a total of $$15\cdot 4 \cdot 30 = 6^2\cdot 50$$ways to roll this case.
 This makes a total of $$6^2 \cdot 100 + 6^2 \cdot 50 = 6^2 \cdot 150 = 6^3 \cdot 25$$ways to roll a pair without rolling a three-of-a-kind.
 So, the probability is $$\frac{\text{successful outcomes}}{\text{total outcomes}}=\frac{6^3 \cdot 25}{6^5}=\frac{25}{6^2}=\boxed{\frac{25}{36}}.$$
 *)

theorem
fixes P :: "rat"
assumes h0 : "P = (25 / 36)"
shows  "P = (Probability_of_exactly_one_pair - Probability_of_three_of_a_kind) / (Number_of_dice_roll_possibilities)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Given that the probability P is equal to $\frac{25}{36}$, find the probability P in terms of the difference between the probability of rolling exactly one pair and the probability of rolling a three-of-a-kind, divided by the total number of possible dice roll outcomes. The final answer is $\frac{25}{36}$.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes dice :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
and P :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>i. 1 \<le> i \<and> i \<le> 6 \<longrightarrow> P i = 1/6"
and h1 : "\<forall>i. dice i \<in> {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6}"
and h2 : "indep_events (\<lambda>i. dice i = i) {1..6}"
and h3 : "three_of_a_kind = (\<Sum> i \<in> {1..6}. P i ^ 3 * (1 - P i) ^ 2)"
and h4 : "one_pair = (\<Sum> i \<in> {1..6}. P i ^ 2 * (1 - P i))"
and h5 : "at_least_one_pair_no_three_of_a_kind = (\<Sum> i \<in> {1..6}. one_pair i - three_of_a_kind i)"
shows  "at_least_one_pair_no_three_of_a_kind = 25 / 36"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Each of five, standard, six-sided dice is rolled once. What is the probability that there is at least one pair but not a three-of-a-kind (that is, there are two dice showing the same value, but no three dice show the same value)? The final Answer is \frac{25}{36}
 ### Proof
 There are a total of $6^5=7776$ possible sets of dice rolls.
 To get a pair without a three-of-a-kind, we can either have one pair and the other three dice all showing different numbers, or we have two pairs and the fifth die showing something different. In the first case, there are $6$ ways to pick which number makes a pair and $\binom{5}{2}=10$ ways to pick which $2$ of the $5$ dice show that number.
 Out of the other three dice, there are $5$ ways to pick a value for the first die so that that die doesn't match the pair, $4$ ways to pick a value for the second one so it doesn't match that die or the pair, and $3$ ways to pick a value for the last die so that it doesn't match any of the others.
 So there are $$6\cdot 10\cdot 5 \cdot 4 \cdot 3 = 6^2 \cdot 100$$ways to roll this case. In the second case, to form two pairs and one die not part of those pairs, there are $\binom{6}{2}=15$ ways to pick which two numbers make the pairs, then $4$ ways to pick a value for the last die so that it doesn't match either of those pairs.
 There are $$\frac{5! }{2!\cdot 2!\cdot 1! }=30$$ways order the five dice (equal to the number of ways to order XXYYZ),  so that makes a total of $$15\cdot 4 \cdot 30 = 6^2\cdot 50$$ways to roll this case.
 This makes a total of $$6^2 \cdot 100 + 6^2 \cdot 50 = 6^2 \cdot 150 = 6^3 \cdot 25$$ways to roll a pair without rolling a three-of-a-kind.
 So, the probability is $$\frac{\text{successful outcomes}}{\text{total outcomes}}=\frac{6^3 \cdot 25}{6^5}=\frac{25}{6^2}=\boxed{\frac{25}{36}}.$$
 *)

theorem
fixes dice :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
and P :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>i. 1 \<le> i \<and> i \<le> 6 \<longrightarrow> P i = 1/6"
and h1 : "\<forall>i. dice i \<in> {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6}"
and h2 : "indep_events (\<lambda>i. dice i = i) {1..6}"
and h3 : "three_of_a_kind = (\<Sum> i \<in> {1..6}. P i ^ 3 * (1 - P i) ^ 2)"
and h4 : "one_pair = (\<Sum> i \<in> {1..6}. P i ^ 2 * (1 - P i))"
and h5 : "at_least_one_pair_no_three_of_a_kind = (\<Sum> i \<in> {1..6}. one_pair i - three_of_a_kind i)"
shows  "at_least_one_pair_no_three_of_a_kind = 25 / 36"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: A fair six-sided die is rolled three times. Find the probability of rolling at least one pair of matching numbers but not three of a kind. The final answer is $\frac{25}{36}$.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes prob_no_pair prob_pair prob_three_of_a_kind :: real
assumes h0 : "prob_no_pair = 5 * (1/6) * (5/6)^4"
and h1 : "prob_pair = 10 * (1/6)^2 * (5/6)^3"
and h2 : "prob_three_of_a_kind = 10 * (1/6)^3 * (5/6)^2"
shows  "prob_pair - prob_three_of_a_kind = 25 / 36"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Each of five, standard, six-sided dice is rolled once. What is the probability that there is at least one pair but not a three-of-a-kind (that is, there are two dice showing the same value, but no three dice show the same value)? The final Answer is \frac{25}{36}
 ### Proof
 There are a total of $6^5=7776$ possible sets of dice rolls.
 To get a pair without a three-of-a-kind, we can either have one pair and the other three dice all showing different numbers, or we have two pairs and the fifth die showing something different. In the first case, there are $6$ ways to pick which number makes a pair and $\binom{5}{2}=10$ ways to pick which $2$ of the $5$ dice show that number.
 Out of the other three dice, there are $5$ ways to pick a value for the first die so that that die doesn't match the pair, $4$ ways to pick a value for the second one so it doesn't match that die or the pair, and $3$ ways to pick a value for the last die so that it doesn't match any of the others.
 So there are $$6\cdot 10\cdot 5 \cdot 4 \cdot 3 = 6^2 \cdot 100$$ways to roll this case. In the second case, to form two pairs and one die not part of those pairs, there are $\binom{6}{2}=15$ ways to pick which two numbers make the pairs, then $4$ ways to pick a value for the last die so that it doesn't match either of those pairs.

 This makes a total of $$6^2 \cdot 100 + 6^2 \cdot 50 = 6^2 \cdot 150 = 6^3 \cdot 25$$ways to roll a pair without rolling a three-of-a-kind.
 So, the probability is $$\frac{\text{successful outcomes}}{\text{total outcomes}}=\frac{6^3 \cdot 25}{6^5}=\frac{25}{6^2}=\boxed{\frac{25}{36}}.$$
 *)

theorem
fixes prob_no_pair prob_pair prob_three_of_a_kind :: real
assumes h0 : "prob_no_pair = 5 * (1/6) * (5/6)^4"
and h1 : "prob_pair = 10 * (1/6)^2 * (5/6)^3"
and h2 : "prob_three_of_a_kind = 10 * (1/6)^3 * (5/6)^2"
shows  "prob_pair - prob_three_of_a_kind = 25 / 36"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem:
Given the probabilities of rolling a dice without a pair, with a pair, and with three of a kind, calculate the difference between the probability of rolling a pair and the probability of rolling three of a kind. The probabilities are given as:

- Probability of no pair: $5 * \frac{1}{6} * (\frac{5}{6})^4$
- Probability of a pair: $10 * (\frac{1}{6})^2 * (\frac{5}{6})^3$
- Probability of three of a kind: $10 * (\frac{1}{6})^3 * (\frac{5}{6})^2$

The final answer is $\frac{25}{36}$.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P :: "real"
assumes h0 : "0 \<le> P"
and h1 : "P \<le> 1"
and h2 : "P = probability_space (at_least_one_pair_but_no_three_of_a_kind)"
shows  "P = 25 / 36"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem

 This makes a total of $$6^2 \cdot 100 + 6^2 \cdot 50 = 6^2 \cdot 150 = 6^3 \cdot 25$$ways to roll a pair without rolling a three-of-a-kind.
 So, the probability is $$\frac{\text{successful outcomes}}{\text{total outcomes}}=\frac{6^3 \cdot 25}{6^5}=\frac{25}{6^2}=\boxed{\frac{25}{36}}.$$
 *)

theorem
fixes P :: "real"
assumes h0 : "0 \<le> P"
and h1 : "P \<le> 1"
and h2 : "P = probability_space (at_least_one_pair_but_no_three_of_a_kind)"
shows  "P = 25 / 36"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: What is the probability of getting at least one pair but no three-of-a-kind in a certain game, given that the probability is denoted by $P$ and $0 \le P \le 1$? The final answer is $\frac{25}{36}$.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p :: real
assumes h0 : "0 \<le> p"
and h1 : "p \<le> 1"
shows  "p = 25 / 36 \<longleftrightarrow> (\<exists> a b c d e. a \<in> {1..6} \<and> b \<in> {1..6} \<and> c \<in> {1..6} \<and> d \<in> {1..6} \<and> e \<in> {1..6} \<and> (card {a, b, c, d, e} = 4) \<and> (\<forall> k \<in> {1..6}. count {a, b, c, d, e} k \<noteq> 3) \<and> (5 choose 2) * (6 choose 1) * (5 choose 1) * p = real (fact 5) / real (fact 6 ^ 5))"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Each of five, standard, six-sided dice is rolled once. What is the probability that there is at least one pair but not a three-of-a-kind (that is, there are two dice showing the same value, but no three dice show the same value)? The final Answer is \frac{25}{36}
 ### Proof
 There are a total of $6^5=7776$ possible sets of dice rolls.
 To get a pair without a three-of-a-kind, we can either have one pair and the other three dice all showing different numbers, or we have two pairs and the fifth die showing something different. In the first case, there are $6$ ways to pick which number makes a pair and $\binom{5}{2}=10$ ways to pick which $2$ of the $5$ dice show that number.
 Out of the other three dice, there are $5$ ways to pick a value for the first die so that that die doesn't match the pair, $4$ ways to pick a value for the second one so it doesn't match that die or the pair, and $3$ ways to pick a value for the last die so that it doesn't match any of the others.
 So there are $$6\cdot 10\cdot 5 \cdot 4 \cdot 3 = 6^2 \cdot 100$$ways to roll this case. In the second case, to form two pairs and one die not part of those pairs, there are $\binom{6}{2}=15$ ways to pick which two numbers make the pairs, then $4$ ways to pick a value for the last die so that it doesn't match either of those pairs.
 There are $$\frac{5! }{2!\cdot 2!\cdot 1! }=30$$ways order the five dice (equal to the number of ways to order XXYYZ),  so that makes a total of $$15\cdot 4 \cdot 30 = 6^2\cdot 50$$ways to roll this case.
 This makes a total of $$6^2 \cdot 100 + 6^2 \cdot 50 = 6^2 \cdot 150 = 6^3 \cdot 25$$ways to roll a pair without rolling a three-of-a-kind.
 So, the probability is $$\frac{\text{successful outcomes}}{\text{total outcomes}}=\frac{6^3 \cdot 25}{6^5}=\frac{25}{6^2}=\boxed{\frac{25}{36}}.$$
 *)

theorem
fixes p :: real
assumes h0 : "0 \<le> p"
and h1 : "p \<le> 1"
shows  "p = 25 / 36 \<longleftrightarrow> (\<exists> a b c d e. a \<in> {1..6} \<and> b \<in> {1..6} \<and> c \<in> {1..6} \<and> d \<in> {1..6} \<and> e \<in> {1..6} \<and> (card {a, b, c, d, e} = 4) \<and> (\<forall> k \<in> {1..6}. count {a, b, c, d, e} k \<noteq> 3) \<and> (5 choose 2) * (6 choose 1) * (5 choose 1) * p = real (fact 5) / real (fact 6 ^ 5))"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: Suppose you have a probability $p$ between 0 and 1. Show that $p = \frac{25}{36}$ if and only if there exist distinct integers $a, b, c, d, e$ between 1 and 6 such that no integer between 1 and 6 appears exactly 3 times in the set $\{a, b, c, d, e\}$, and the probability $p$ can be expressed as the ratio of the product of $\binom{5}{2}$, $\binom{6}{1}$, and $\binom{5}{1}$ to the factorial of 5 divided by the factorial of 6 raised to the power of 5.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes probability :: "real"
assumes h0 : "probability = (\<Sum>i \<in> {1..6}. (\<Sum>j \<in> {1..6} - {i}. (\<Sum>k \<in> {1..6} - {i, j}. 
                  (1 / 6) * (1 / 6) * (1 / 6) * (1 / 6) * (1 / 6))))"
shows  "probability = 25 / 36"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Each of five, standard, six-sided dice is rolled once. What is the probability that there is at least one pair but not a three-of-a-kind (that is, there are two dice showing the same value, but no three dice show the same value)? The final Answer is \frac{25}{36}
 ### Proof
 There are a total of $6^5=7776$ possible sets of dice rolls.
 To get a pair without a three-of-a-kind, we can either have one pair and the other three dice all showing different numbers, or we have two pairs and the fifth die showing something different. In the first case, there are $6$ ways to pick which number makes a pair and $\binom{5}{2}=10$ ways to pick which $2$ of the $5$ dice show that number.
 Out of the other three dice, there are $5$ ways to pick a value for the first die so that that die doesn't match the pair, $4$ ways to pick a value for the second one so it doesn't match that die or the pair, and $3$ ways to pick a value for the last die so that it doesn't match any of the others.
 So there are $$6\cdot 10\cdot 5 \cdot 4 \cdot 3 = 6^2 \cdot 100$$ways to roll this case. In the second case, to form two pairs and one die not part of those pairs, there are $\binom{6}{2}=15$ ways to pick which two numbers make the pairs, then $4$ ways to pick a value for the last die so that it doesn't match either of those pairs.
 There are $$\frac{5! }{2!\cdot 2!\cdot 1! }=30$$ways order the five dice (equal to the number of ways to order XXYYZ),  so that makes a total of $$15\cdot 4 \cdot 30 = 6^2\cdot 50$$ways to roll this case.
 This makes a total of $$6^2 \cdot 100 + 6^2 \cdot 50 = 6^2 \cdot 150 = 6^3 \cdot 25$$ways to roll a pair without rolling a three-of-a-kind.
 So, the probability is $$\frac{\text{successful outcomes}}{\text{total outcomes}}=\frac{6^3 \cdot 25}{6^5}=\frac{25}{6^2}=\boxed{\frac{25}{36}}.$$
 *)

theorem
fixes probability :: "real"
assumes h0 : "probability = (\<Sum>i \<in> {1..6}. (\<Sum>j \<in> {1..6} - {i}. (\<Sum>k \<in> {1..6} - {i, j}. 
                  (1 / 6) * (1 / 6) * (1 / 6) * (1 / 6) * (1 / 6))))"
shows  "probability = 25 / 36"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: Calculate the probability that when rolling three 6-sided dice, no two dice show the same number. The final answer is $\frac{25}{36}$.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P :: "real" and dice :: "nat"
assumes h0 : "dice = 5"
and h1 : "P = (\<Sum>i\<in>{(a,b,c,d,e) | a b c d e. a \<in> {1..6} \<and> b \<in> {1..6} \<and> c \<in> {1..6} \<and> d \<in> {1..6} \<and> e \<in> {1..6} \<and> (\<exists>x y z. x \<noteq> y \<and> x \<noteq> z \<and> y \<noteq> z \<and> a = x \<and> b = y \<and> c = y \<and> d = z \<and> e = z)}. 1)"
shows  "P = 25 / 36"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Each of five, standard, six-sided dice is rolled once. What is the probability that there is at least one pair but not a three-of-a-kind (that is, there are two dice showing the same value, but no three dice show the same value)? The final Answer is \frac{25}{36}

 Out of the other three dice, there are $5$ ways to pick a value for the first die so that that die doesn't match the pair, $4$ ways to pick a value for the second one so it doesn't match that die or the pair, and $3$ ways to pick a value for the last die so that it doesn't match any of the others.

In the second case, to form two pairs and one die not part of those pairs, there are $\binom{6}{2}=15$ ways to pick which two numbers make the pairs, then $4$ ways to pick a value for the last die so that it doesn't match either of those pairs.
 There are $$\frac{5! }{2!\cdot 2!\cdot 1! }=30$$ways order the five dice (equal to the number of ways to order XXYYZ),  so that makes a total of $$15\cdot 4 \cdot 30 = 6^2\cdot 50$$ways to roll this case.
 This makes a total of $$6^2 \cdot 100 + 6^2 \cdot 50 = 6^2 \cdot 150 = 6^3 \cdot 25$$ways to roll a pair without rolling a three-of-a-kind.
 So, the probability is $$\frac{\text{successful outcomes}}{\text{total outcomes}}=\frac{6^3 \cdot 25}{6^5}=\frac{25}{6^2}=\boxed{\frac{25}{36}}.$$
 *)

theorem
fixes P :: "real" and dice :: "nat"
assumes h0 : "dice = 5"
and h1 : "P = (\<Sum>i\<in>{(a,b,c,d,e) | a b c d e. a \<in> {1..6} \<and> b \<in> {1..6} \<and> c \<in> {1..6} \<and> d \<in> {1..6} \<and> e \<in> {1..6} \<and> (\<exists>x y z. x \<noteq> y \<and> x \<noteq> z \<and> y \<noteq> z \<and> a = x \<and> b = y \<and> c = y \<and> d = z \<and> e = z)}. 1)"
shows  "P = 25 / 36"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: In a five-dice roll, what is the probability that there are exactly two pairs of same-numbered dice, and the fifth dice shows a different number? The final answer is $\frac{25}{36}$.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes prob_at_least_one_pair_not_three_of_a_kind :: real
assumes h0 : "0 \<le> prob_at_least_one_pair_not_three_of_a_kind"
and h1 : "prob_at_least_one_pair_not_three_of_a_kind \<le> 1"
and h2 : "prob_at_least_one_pair_not_three_of_a_kind = (25 / 36)"
shows  "prob_at_least_one_pair_not_three_of_a_kind = 25 / 36"
a_7.formal solution:

theorem
fixes prob_at_least_one_pair_not_three_of_a_kind :: real
assumes h0 : "0 \<le> prob_at_least_one_pair_not_three_of_a_kind"
and h1 : "prob_at_least_one_pair_not_three_of_a_kind \<le> 1"
and h2 : "prob_at_least_one_pair_not_three_of_a_kind = (25 / 36)"
shows  "prob_at_least_one_pair_not_three_of_a_kind = 25 / 36"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: What is the probability of having at least one pair but not a three-of-a-kind? The final answer is $\frac{25}{36}$.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes probability :: real and dice_faces :: nat
assumes h0 : "dice_faces = 6"
and h1 : "probability = (\<lambda>x. real x / real (dice_faces ^ 5))"
shows  "probability (card {S. S \<subseteq> {1..dice_faces} \<and> card S = 4 \<and> (\<exists> a b c d. a \<noteq> b \<and> S = {a, a, b, c, d})}) = 25 / 36"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Each of five, standard, six-sided dice is rolled once. What is the probability that there is at least one pair but not a three-of-a-kind (that is, there are two dice showing the same value, but no three dice show the same value)? The final Answer is \frac{25}{36}
 ### Proof
 There are a total of $6^5=7776$ possible sets of dice rolls.
 To get a pair without a three-of-a-kind, we can either have one pair and the other three dice all showing different numbers, or we have two pairs and the fifth die showing something different. In the first case, there are $6$ ways to pick which number makes a pair and $\binom{5}{2}=10$ ways to pick which $2$ of the $5$ dice show that number.
 Out of the other three dice, there are $5$ ways to pick a value for the first die so that that die doesn't match the pair, $4$ ways to pick a value for the second one so it doesn't match that die or the pair, and $3$ ways to pick a value for the last die so that it doesn't match any of the others.
 So there are $$6\cdot 10\cdot 5 \cdot 4 \cdot 3 = 6^2 \cdot 100$$ways to roll this case. In the second case, to form two pairs and one die not part of those pairs, there are $\binom{6}{2}=15$ ways to pick which two numbers make the pairs, then $4$ ways to pick a value for the last die so that it doesn't match either of those pairs.
 There are $$\frac{5! }{2!\cdot 2!\cdot 1! }=30$$ways order the five dice (equal to the number of ways to order XXYYZ),  so that makes a total of $$15\cdot 4 \cdot 30 = 6^2\cdot 50$$ways to roll this case.
 This makes a total of $$6^2 \cdot 100 + 6^2 \cdot 50 = 6^2 \cdot 150 = 6^3 \cdot 25$$ways to roll a pair without rolling a three-of-a-kind.
 So, the probability is $$\frac{\text{successful outcomes}}{\text{total outcomes}}=\frac{6^3 \cdot 25}{6^5}=\frac{25}{6^2}=\boxed{\frac{25}{36}}.$$
 *)

theorem
fixes probability :: real and dice_faces :: nat
assumes h0 : "dice_faces = 6"
and h1 : "probability = (\<lambda>x. real x / real (dice_faces ^ 5))"
shows  "probability (card {S. S \<subseteq> {1..dice_faces} \<and> card S = 4 \<and> (\<exists> a b c d. a \<noteq> b \<and> S = {a, a, b, c, d})}) = 25 / 36"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: A fair 6-sided die is rolled 5 times. What is the probability that exactly two faces appear twice and the remaining face appears once? The final answer is $\frac{25}{36}$.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P :: "real set"
assumes h0 : "finite P"
and h1 : "card P = 5"
and h2 : "P \<subseteq> {1..6}"
and h3 : "distinct (map (\<lambda>x. card {y \<in> P. x = y}) (map (\<lambda>x. card {y \<in> P. x = y}) [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6]))"
and h4 : "\<forall>x \<in> P. card {y \<in> P. x = y} \<le> 3"
and h5 : "\<exists>x \<in> P. card {y \<in> P. x = y} = 2"
shows  "measure (count_space P) {x. x \<in> P \<and> (\<exists> a b c d e. a \<noteq> b \<and> c \<noteq> d \<and> c \<noteq> e \<and> d \<noteq> e \<and> a = c \<and> b = d)} = 25 / 36"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Each of five, standard, six-sided dice is rolled once. What is the probability that there is at least one pair but not a three-of-a-kind (that is, there are two dice showing the same value, but no three dice show the same value)? The final Answer is \frac{25}{36}
 ### Proof
 There are a total of $6^5=7776$ possible sets of dice rolls.
 To get a pair without a three-of-a-kind, we can either have one pair and the other three dice all showing different numbers, or we have two pairs and the fifth die showing something different. In the first case, there are $6$ ways to pick which number makes a pair and $\binom{5}{2}=10$ ways to pick which $2$ of the $5$ dice show that number.
 Out of the other three dice, there are $5$ ways to pick a value for the first die so that that die doesn't match the pair, $4$ ways to pick a value for the second one so it doesn't match that die or the pair, and $3$ ways to pick a value for the last die so that it doesn't match any of the others.
 So there are $$6\cdot 10\cdot 5 \cdot 4 \cdot 3 = 6^2 \cdot 100$$ways to roll this case. In the second case, to form two pairs and one die not part of those pairs, there are $\binom{6}{2}=15$ ways to pick which two numbers make the pairs, then $4$ ways to pick a value for the last die so that it doesn't match either of those pairs.
 There are $$\frac{5! }{2!\cdot 2!\cdot 1! }=30$$ways order the five dice (equal to the number of ways to order XXYYZ),  so that makes a total of $$15\cdot 4 \cdot 30 = 6^2\cdot 50$$ways to roll this case.
 This makes a total of $$6^2 \cdot 100 + 6^2 \cdot 50 = 6^2 \cdot 150 = 6^3 \cdot 25$$ways to roll a pair without rolling a three-of-a-kind.
 So, the probability is $$\frac{\text{successful outcomes}}{\text{total outcomes}}=\frac{6^3 \cdot 25}{6^5}=\frac{25}{6^2}=\boxed{\frac{25}{36}}.$$
 *)

theorem
fixes P :: "real set"
assumes h0 : "finite P"
and h1 : "card P = 5"
and h2 : "P \<subseteq> {1..6}"
and h3 : "distinct (map (\<lambda>x. card {y \<in> P. x = y}) (map (\<lambda>x. card {y \<in> P. x = y}) [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6]))"
and h4 : "\<forall>x \<in> P. card {y \<in> P. x = y} \<le> 3"
and h5 : "\<exists>x \<in> P. card {y \<in> P. x = y} = 2"
shows  "measure (count_space P) {x. x \<in> P \<and> (\<exists> a b c d e. a \<noteq> b \<and> c \<noteq> d \<and> c \<noteq> e \<and> d \<noteq> e \<and> a = c \<and> b = d)} = 25 / 36"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Let P be a finite set of real numbers with exactly 5 elements, all of which are integers from 1 to 6 inclusive. The number of times each element occurs in P is distinct. No element occurs more than 3 times, and at least one element occurs exactly twice. What is the probability that there exist distinct elements a, b, c, d, and e in P such that a is equal to c and b is equal to d? The final answer is $\frac{25}{36}$.
